description: Find a BFPO number, send mail to and from British forces personnel and their families

parts.body:
You can use the British Forces Post Office (BFPO) to send a letter or parcel to:

  • serving armed forces personnel and their families
  • an employee of the Ministry of Defence (MOD), or another official organisation, who’s entitled to use BFPO

How to use the BFPO

You must:

  1. Check how to address BFPO mail.

  2. Check the list of what you cannot send.

  3. If you’re sending a parcel, fill out a customs declaration form.

If you do not do these things, your post could be lost, delayed, destroyed or returned to you.

Consider the best way to post your item based on the value, cost, size and weight.

Allow plenty of time for your post to arrive. It can take several weeks.

Maximum weights

The most your parcel can weigh is usually:

  • 20kg if you post it at a Post Office
  • 30kg if you order something with a UK-based online retailer

Some destinations have a lower weight limit.

Get help with the BFPO

Contact BFPO if you need help or support.

BFPO enquiries
bfpoenquiries@bfpo.info

Telephone for general questions: 0345 769 7978

Telephone for civilian questions: 020 8589 3450
Telephone for military questions: 94676 3450

Monday to Thursday, 8am to 3:30pm
Friday, 8am to 2:30pm
Lines closed on bank holidays

Find out about call charges

parts.title: Find a BFPO number

parts.body:
You must:

  • use a printed address label or write the address clearly in capital letters
  • use the correct address format
  • use the BFPO number to address mail, not the location (town or country)
  • write a return address on the back of the mail clearly in block capital letters
  • include your full name and postcode in the return address
  • if you’re sending a parcel, fill out a customs declaration form and stick it to the outside of your post

If you’re posting mail from outside the UK, write ‘GB’ after the BFPO number.

Do not write anything else on the packaging.

You cannot use pre-printed Royal Mail postage labels, for example Click and Drop, to send post to the UK from overseas.

Address format

SERVICE NUMBER, RANK or TITLE, and NAME
UNIT or REGIMENT or HM SHIP
OPERATION (if deployed)
BFPO number

For family members start with:

NAME OF DEPENDANT C/O SERVICE NUMBER, RANK and NAME

For non-service personnel start with:

STAFF NUMBER (if available) NAME
parts.title: How to address BFPO mail

parts.body:
You must complete a customs declaration if you’re sending a parcel. Write clearly and stick it to the outside of your post so it’s easy to read.

You must use either:

  • form CN22 for contents worth up to £270
  • form CN23 for contents worth more than £270

If you’re a business, you must add a commodity code (also known as Harmonised Systems Code) to the customs form. Check which code you need.
parts.title: Customs declarations

parts.body:
The cost of using British Forces Post Office (BFPO) depends on the size and weight of the letter or parcel you’re sending.

You might be able to send mail for free using the enduring families free mail service.

If you’re posting your parcel at a post office, it must weigh less than 20kg.

BFPO cannot deliver post by a certain time or date.

Standard letter

Length: up to 240mm
Width: up to 165mm
Thickness: up to 5mm

Weight range Cost
Up to 100g £1.25

Large letter

Length: up to 353mm
Width: up to 250mm
Thickness: up to 25mm

Weight range Cost
Up to 100g £1.95
101g to 250g £2.70
251g to 750g £3.30

Small parcels

Length: up to 450mm
Width: up to 350mm
Thickness: up to 160mm

Weight range Cost
Up to 2kg £4.19

If you’re sending a parcel that’s a tube shape, double the diameter and add this to the length. The total cannot be more than 1,040mm. The biggest dimension cannot be more than 900mm.

Medium parcels

Length: up to 610mm
Width: up to 460mm
Thickness: up to 460mm

Weight range Cost
Up to 2kg £6.29
Up to 10kg £7.99
Up to 20kg £11.99

Worldwide parcels

You can send parcels to a BFPO address outside of the UK at a Post Office using Royal Mail.

Parcels can be up to 20kg.

Cost depends on the size of the parcel.

Maximum weight Cost
Up to 2kg (small) £4.45
Up to 2kg (medium) £6.95
Up to 10kg £7.95
Up to 20kg £12.95

You must make a customs declaration if you’re sending a parcel with BFPO.

You cannot use ParcelForce to send parcels with BFPO unless you have a business account with them. If you have an account, you can send parcels up to 30kg.

Insuring your post in case of loss or damage

You should always:

  • ask for proof of posting at the Post Office
  • keep proof of how much your item is worth

If your post is lost or damaged you may be able to claim standard compensation up to £20.

If your item is worth more than £20, you can pay for extra cover at the Post Office using:

  • Royal Mail Signed For - this allows you to claim compensation up to £50
  • Royal Mail Special Delivery - this allows you claim compensation up to £2500 

You cannot take out Royal Mail Consequential Loss cover when you post something with BFPO.
parts.title: Cost, size and weight

parts.body:
Not all UK online retailers are able to send things to a BFPO address. Check with the retailer before you order anything.

Your online order must:

  • weigh less than 30kg
  • have a length, depth and width that adds up to less than 2 metres, a single side must not be more than 1 metre 5cm

If you are ordering online, allow plenty of time for your order to be delivered.

Do not use a BFPO address that starts with BF1 when you order online.

When the retailer posts your order

They should:

  • check how to address BFPO mail
  • attach a customs declaration or commercial invoice to the outside of the parcel 
  • include commodity codes on the customs form - they can check which code to use
  • insure any goods they send in case of loss or damage 
  • charge you UK postage rates, not international delivery prices

They can post your mail using Post Office, Royal Mail, Parcel Force or an approved courier company from the following list:

  • DHL Express
  • DPD 
  • DX Network Services 
  • FedEx UK 
  • Flight Logistics Group
  • Hermes Parcelnet
  • Secured Mail
  • TNT
  • Yodel

Some retailers have a special arrangement for posting mail with BFPO - this is called Commercial Receipts. They can email BFPO if they want to set this up.

BFPO Commercial Receipts enquiries
DESBFPO-Team-Comrcl@mod.gov.uk

Sending orders to Cyprus or the Falkland Islands

If you are online shopping and your order will be delivered to Cyprus or the Falkland Islands, the retailer can use a premium service to post your order.

Your order must:

  • weigh less than 30kg
  • have a length, depth and width that adds up to less than 3 metres, a single side must not be more than 1 metre 50cm

Leave plenty of time for your order to be delivered.
parts.title: Online shopping

parts.body:
You cannot send some items in BFPO mail, including:

  • alcohol
  • arms and ammunition
  • batteries
  • Christmas crackers
  • financial documents that you cannot replace if lost (not including bank statements or cards)
  • flammable liquids (except up to 150ml of perfume or aftershave to UK locations)
  • fragile items
  • indecent, obscene or offensive material
  • liquids classified as dangerous goods
  • over 1 litre of liquids per parcel
  • prescription medicines and drugs sent for scientific purposes
  • pressurised containers (including aerosols like deodorants and shaving foams or gels)
  • sharp objects and instruments (including scissors and kitchen knives or utensils)

If you send these items, your whole parcel may be delayed or returned to you.

If you are not sure, check the Royal Mail list of what you can and cannot send.
parts.title: What you cannot send

parts.body:
You can send letters (also known as ‘blueys’) and parcels for free to service personnel who are on certain ships or operations through the enduring families free mail service. Check which operations and ships are eligible.

You can only use this service to send mail to people that you know.

How to use the service

Address your letter or parcel using the same address format as other BFPO mail.

You must include:

  • a return address
  • a customs declaration form with a tick in the box marked ‘gift’

Post your letter at either a Post Box or Post Office.

Post your parcel at a Post Office.

Size and weight

Your letter or parcel must be at least 9cm by 14cm. The length, depth and width must not add up to more than 90cm. A single side must not be more than 60cm.

Your parcel must not weigh more than 2kg.

What you cannot send

You cannot send:

  • pressurised containers, such as aerosols, shaving foam or alcohol
  • items worth more than £35 or €45

Check the full list of what you cannot send.
parts.title: Use the enduring families free mail service

parts.body:
You may be able to claim compensation if your post:

  • does not arrive within 30 working days 
  • is damaged when it arrives 

You must make your claim within 80 days of the date you posted the item.

How much you can claim

You can claim the money you paid for postage plus the value of any items lost.

You can claim up to:

  • £20 for items posted at a Post Office
  • £100 for items posted with Parcel Force

You may be able to claim extra compensation if you paid for this at the time of posting.

If a company or retailer sent the item then you should check with them.

Who can claim

The person who sent the post should make the claim.

If you bought something online, the retailer who posted the item should make the claim.

How to make a claim

If you are in the UK, you can either:

  • collect a lost or damaged claim form from your local Post Office 
  • ask the BFPO service desk to send you a form by email

Fill in the form and send it to the BFPO service desk, along with any supporting documents.

BFPO service desk
bfpoenquiries@bfpo.info

HQ BFPO,
West End Road,
Ruislip HA4 6DQ

Telephone for general questions: 0345 769 7978
Telephone for civilian questions: 020 8589 3450
Telephone for military questions: 94676 3450 Monday to Thursday, 8am to 3:30pm, Friday, 8am to 2:30pm
Lines closed on bank holidays Find out about call charges

What to include in your claim

You’ll need to provide:

  • the delivery name and address
  • the name and address of the sender
  • which postal service you used and any tracking numbers
  • when and where you posted the item
  • proof of postage
  • proof of purchase – to show how much the item that was lost or damaged was worth
  • if you’re claiming for damage, pictures of the damage and original packaging
